texts.value: Protein tyrosine phosphatase which stimulates progression from G1 into S phase during mitosis. Enhances cell proliferation, cell motility and invasive activity, and promotes cancer metastasis. May be involved in the progression of cardiac hypertrophy by inhibiting intracellular calcium mobilization in response to angiotensin II
Inhibited by sodium orthovanadate and peroxovanadium compounds, and by pentamidine
Mainly expressed in cardiomyocytes and skeletal muscle; also found in pancreas. Consistently overexpressed in colon cancer metastasis
Farnesylated. Farnesylation is required for membrane targeting (By similarity)
Belongs to the protein-tyrosine phosphatase family

citation.title: Full-length of some muscular transcripts, Telethon (Italy) project B41.
Cloning of human full-length CDSs in BD Creator(TM) system donor vector.
The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).
Multiple phosphotyrosine phosphatase mRNAs are expressed in the human lung fibroblast cell line WI-38.
Role of PRL-3, a human muscle-specific tyrosine phosphatase, in angiotensin-II signaling.
A phosphatase associated with metastasis of colorectal cancer.
The tyrosine phosphatase PRL-1 localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum and the mitotic spindle and is required for normal mitosis.
Pentamidine is an inhibitor of PRL phosphatases with anticancer activity.
PRL-3 and PRL-1 promote cell migration, invasion, and metastasis.
Structure of human PRL-3, the phosphatase associated with cancer metastasis.
Structural insights into molecular function of the metastasis-associated phosphatase PRL-3.

referencePositions: MUTAGENESIS OF CYS-49; ASP-71; ASP-72 AND ALA-111
